Hi Etan,

Having tried to follow the discussion uf-discuss, I'm not clear  =

exactly why we're still arguing about it. Though, I'm glad we're  
discuss=
ing it here, where we have more REST experts.

In case it helps, here's how=
 I summarized the "URL opacity"  
discussion over on uf-rest:

http://micro=
formats.org/wiki/rest/opacity

Does that provide any insight?

-- Ernie P.
=


On Oct 24, 2006, at 11:45 PM, Etan Wexler wrote:

> Mike Schinkel started=
 a thread of discussion on the mailing list
> Microformats Discuss. The mes=
sage that opens the thread is =93[uf- 
> discuss]
> "Casual Web Services" a=
nd Well Designed Urls=94
> (<http://microformats.org/discuss/mail/microform=
ats-discuss/2006- 
> October/006341.html>).
>
> I am, in this message, repl=
ying to Mike Schinkel=92s =93[uf-discuss]  
> "Casual
> Web Services" and W=
ell Designed Urls[uf-rest]=94
> (<http://microformats.org/discuss/mail/micr=
oformats-rest/2006- 
> October/000300.html>):
>
> > Etan Wexler wrote:
> >
=
> >> The structure of URLs is not important knowledge for any API for
> >> =
applications of REST. In fact, the structure of URLs is totally  
> irrelev=
ant
> >> to any such API.
> >
> > [...] Can you please provide justificatio=
n?
>
> I gave the justification, albeit briefly, in a previous message
> (<=
http://microformats.org/discuss/mail/microformats-rest/2006- 
> October/000=
292.html>):
>
> =91REST does not permit programmatic construction of URIs i=
n which the
> construction uses of out-of-band knowledge and bits of data. =
Read
> sections 5.1.5 (=93Uniform Interface=94,
> <http://www.ics.uci.edu/~=
fielding/pubs/dissertation/ 
> rest_arch_style.htm#sec_5_1_5>)
>
> and 5.2.=
1 (=93Data Elements=94,
> <http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertati=
on/ 
> rest_arch_style.htm#sec_5_2_1>)
> of =93Architectural Styles and the=
 Design of Network-based Software
> Architectures=94. Particularly, REST re=
lies on hypermedia as the  
> engine of
> application state, while construc=
ting URIs violates this constraint.=92
>
> Mike, you responded, =93After re=
ading your email and those sections of
> Roy's paper I have absolutely no i=
dea what you were trying to
> communicate to me. Roy's paper is written in =
such abstract language  
> that
> I am unable to see the issues you bring u=
p.=94
> (<http://microformats.org/discuss/mail/microformats-rest/2006- 
> O=
ctober/000293.html>)
>
> I then stated my position
> (<http://microformats.=
org/discuss/mail/microformats-rest/2006- 
> October/000296.html>),
> for wh=
ich you requested justification. Here we find ourselves.
>
> In the meantim=
e, I clarified =93constructing URIs=94 as meaning =93a  
> computer
> progr=
am=92s construction of URIs, as opposed to a human=92s  
> construction of
=
> URIs=94
> (<http://microformats.org/discuss/mail/microformats-rest/2006- =

> October/000297.html>).
>
> I clarified my definition of =93out-of-band k=
nowledge=94
> (<http://microformats.org/discuss/mail/microformats-rest/2006=
- 
> October/000299.html>).
>
> > [After you sent] your email someone else =
emailed contradicting  
> you and he gave
> > copious references to support=
 his point.
>
> Yes, Nick Gall contradicted me
> (<http://microformats.org/=
discuss/mail/microformats-rest/2006- 
> October/000294.html>).
> His refere=
nces are to non-authoritative materials that do not
> contradict me.
>
> > =
So if your justification is [Tim Berners-Lee] saying that URLs  
> need be
=
> > be opaque, I can provide links [...]
>
> My justification has nothing t=
o do with the statements of Tim  
> Berners-Lee.
>
> >> When a program impl=
ements an API for an application of REST, the  
> program
> >> relies on th=
e presence of links in content. And when the program  
> sifts
> >> content=
 to discover links (rather than constructing URIs  
> according to
> >> exp=
lanations)...
> >
> > That is not necessarily true. It can be one valid use=
-case but is  
> not all
> > valid use-cases.
>
> What do you make of the f=
ollowing two passages?
>
> =93Hypermedia is defined by the presence of appl=
ication control
> information embedded within, or as a layer above, the pre=
sentation of
> information.=94
> (<http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/di=
ssertation/ 
> web_arch_domain.htm#sec_4_1_3>)
>
> =93REST is defined by fo=
ur interface constraints: identification of
> resources; manipulation of re=
sources through representations;
> self-descriptive messages; and, hypermed=
ia as the engine of  
> application
> state.=94
> (<http://www.ics.uci.edu/=
~fielding/pubs/dissertation/ 
> rest_arch_style.htm#sec_5_1_5>)
>
> > The s=
tructure of the links are [relevant in] other use-cases.
>
> I presume that=
 =93links=94 here means URLs or some other resource  
> identifiers.
>
> > =
Take a look at the NING REST API [...]; it does exactly what I'm
> > descri=
bing (and I can give other examples which I will be doing  
> on the
> > bl=
og):
> >
> > http://documentation.ning.com/sections/rest.php
> >
> > Here's=
 Eventful's EVDB api:
> >
> > http://api.evdb.com/docs
> >
> > Here's del.i=
cio.us:
> >
> > http://del.icio.us/help/api/posts
>
> I read through the do=
cumentation that you cited. The subjects of the
> documentation (that is, t=
he software systems and their APIs) break  
> from
> REST in various ways. =
If these systems, their APIs, or their
> documentation do exactly what your=
e describing, then you=92re describing
> something that does not fit within=
 REST.
>
> The key issue is that none of the cited materials are authoritat=
ive.
>
> -- 
>
>
> 


--Apple-Mail-6-947721888
